Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History Collections: Developing Ericaceae research resources through collections enhancement and data integration
Award.AbstractNarration:
The plant family Ericaceae (4000 species) has a global distribution and includes economically important members, such as blueberries, cranberries, and rhododendrons. The New York Botanical Garden (NYBG) received an award to updated species identifications, curate, refurbish with archival storage materials, image, and database Ericaceae research specimens at both NYBG and Rutgers University. The unique assemblage, which supports biodiversity research, includes herbarium specimens, liquid preserved tissue, anatomical microscope slides, wood, DNA samples, and images of living plants. Computerization upgraded to a web framework will enable the integration and simultaneous searching of all these collections.

Education is a primary intellectual merit of this project. A doctoral student will receive two years of support while being trained in the stewardship of an array of natural history collections. NYBG also develops under-represented groups by training students, interns and international collaborators. Upgrading collections infrastructure and electronic data dissemination will facilitate collections use in educational endeavors beyond NYBG. Using these research materials, an on-line atlas of Ericaceae anatomy and a K-12 teachers workshop will be developed. A symposium will educate Rutgers University biology under- and graduate-students about NYBG's collections as a global tool for research, education, and ex situ conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project integrated resources for biodiversity research on the plant family Ericaceae held at the New York Botanical Garden (NYBG) and in the  Chrysler Herbarium (CHRB) of Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey. Ericaceae have a global distribution and comprise almost 4000 species in about 125 genera, including economically important members (e.g., rhododendrons, and blue- and cran-berries). Lineages, such as Vaccinieae, are especially diverse in the neotropics and many are endemic to endangered habitats. The New York Botanical Garden has a long history (since the late 1920s) of research and graduate training in the systematics of Ericaceae and Rutgers has long term floristic and ecological investigations in the region, where the family is an important component of the Pine Barrens flora. Resources included herbarium specimens from NYBG and CHRB, and specimen and live plant images, and laboratory collections housed at NYBG.

Laboratory collections, including a large donation from Rutgers, consist of samples for DNA-based research; seeds used for identification; wood (used in modern systematic and climate change research, and as a reference for forensic science); preparations of pollen and other structures for microscopic study (e.g., leaf clearings used in systematic research and in interpreting the fossil record), including many serial sections (e.g., of floral and fruit development); and fluid-preserved specimens. The latter are used in taxonomic, anatomical, morphological, and genomic research. The Mertz Library and living collections at NYBG and Rutgers's Philip E. Marucci Center for Blueberry and Cranberry Research complement these integrated resources.

Several Assistants and an Intern, many from groups under represented in the sciences, learned a complex database, resources used to interpret natural history collection specimen labels, curation of diverse botanical collections, and policies for natural history collection stewardship. Among the Assistants were a Ph.D. student supported by this project who was studying the systematics of a neotropical genus of Ericaceae, and a Master's student in Museum Studies.

Modules for an existing KE EMu database application were enhanced to integrate information about the nature, condition, and storage location of laboratory samples with the existing database for herbarium specimens, images, literature, and management functions. The materials used for curation, and data schema, procedures, and work flow developed during this project can be adopted by other organizations.

The specimens and samples can be simultaneously searched for on the "Ericaceae Pages" website (http://sweetgum.nybg.org/science/projects/ericaceae). This research tool includes an overview of the family; phylogenetic information; specimen checklists; images; descriptions, including species descriptions from Flora Neotropica digitized for the World Flora Online project; other literature; distribution maps; and links to external resources (e.g., to a search site for NYBG's living collections). Updates to the database are immediately available on-line through NYBG's "Virtual Herbarium"; thus, the project website will continue to be updated after the end of this project. The searchable website not only makes data and collections available to scientists and students around the world, but data on plant distributions in space and time can be used by biodiversity researchers outside of botany (e.g., ornithologists), those documenting and understanding the effects of climate change, and anyone with an interest in plants.
